Money spent feeding the kids of parents who can't, or won't, feed their own children is "education spending." Money spent counseling the kids of parents who can't, or won't, parent is "education spending." Money spent on educationally useless tests, and the preparation for them, is "education spending."

None of these things have anything to do with education. We've got lots of "education spending" in America, but very little spending on education.
that was one of my points.  keeping children well promotes education but is not, in itself, education.  if it were, there would be a lot more time spent in physical education activities.

My impression from talking to my colleagues from other countries is that schools there are not expected to be social service agencies as they are here. I also suspect that there is an inverse relation between the extent to which a school is expected to be a social service agency and the amount of its budget that is actually spent directly on students' academic progress.  This could explain why teachers here are not paid as well and why it is harder to attract those who are interested in passing on their love of the subject matter in which they are expert.  I know from my own experience that until I learned that a love of mathematics and teaching it to others did not mean a profession where I was expected to see who was smoking in the boys' room or supervising lunch rooms did I decide to go to college and become a mathematician.  You would not catch me dead teaching mathematics in a public high school because it is not really about teaching in such a place. My reluctance  is not about the material, as I have spent significant time teaching middle school and high school level mathematics to college students, it is the professional environment in which it takes place.

What is a successful school?
For me personally a successful school is one that allows its students to find a path in life that provides joy, self appreciation and a sense of belonging.
As someone who has been out of school for over forty years I am still angered by the years stolen from my imagination and every failure that robbed me of my self esteem.
For me a successful school would have been one that recognized that the organization and the skill set necessary that school might service was not one that the traditional schoolroom could provide.For information sponges like myself whose short term memory is way below par but who long tern retention is off the scale school failed me and but for the fortune of a very caring family and tremendous good fortune in finding good friends this comment would surely never have appeared.
Schools should be only one aspect of an education system that is geared to the needs of the students. I am sure I am not alone in stating that my time in school after age five might have been better spent in a library.I am a retired happy, loving and appreciative human being. My time spent in what is deemed a very successful school and school system is nothing but unpleasant memories. It is only the last 30 years where I have reconciled my inability to perform academically with the impossibility of my being who and what I am rather than a character flaw or some other personal failing.
I do know good teachers and they are a treasure.

Almost 20 years ago a study was done comparing the schools in a Swiss city with an American city of comparable size. The money each city spent on educating its students was about the same, as was the approximate demographic makeup of the students. That is where the similarities ended. The Swiss city invested almost all its resources in its teachers, who were well-paid and well-respected. The teachers in the American city were paid about average for teachers in the U.S., and were not treated as professionals in charge of determining how best to educate the students in their classes. Many of them were forced to follow canned/scripted lessons purchased expressly to "teacher-proof" the classrooms. The Swiss schools did not have district administrators costing about ten cents out of every dollar with little or no impact on student learning. The Swiss schools did not offer several dozen different programs with virtually no evidence that they helped students learn. The American schools, on the other hand, purchased dozens of programs that enriched the publishing companies, but had virtually no impact on student learning. And, the Swiss students outperformed the American students by significant margins.

We knew then what worked, and we know it now. There is just too much money being made by publishers and testing companies to transform our schools into learning centers focused on student learning instead of profit centers run for the benefit of bureaucrats and corporations.
That is a very good, clear explanation.

Until parents are directly involved with the schools in the responsibility of guiding their children's education at home this is not a serious discussion. A child's primary example of character traits such as sustained attention and persistence is taken from the parents, not the teachers. A child will consciously or unconsciously meet the parents expectations and involvement (or lack thereof). It is the parent, after all, with whom they live and depend upon for their entire existence and lasting approval, not various teachers.

While the examination of the successes and failures of the various methods of educational institutions is necessary, it is equally necessary to study households, particularly in low income brackets, where the parent-child relationship results in consistent academic success compared to those households where children consistently fail. Academic success is never an accident of luck - it is manufactured through constructive habits. Let us not be afraid to learn from those households that can teach us how to be better stewards of the young.

As a professional public school educator for 50 years I couldn't agree more with some many of these comments. Reforming schools is simpler then the we have made it. Tucker says it all: "The main thing that works is treating teaching as a profession, and teachers as professionals." Professionalization of teaching means both more authority and more accountability. When I began teaching in 1959 teachers in my public school system ( 13,000 students, 28 schools), were highly respected by students, parents, and their community. That the school was nationally recognized helped, but what was more important was that the community believed their teachers would educate every child and held us accountable for that.  In return we were given real authority to teach and were expected to collaborate and innovate recognizing good schools need to continuously improve. That culture made it a place where teachers wanted to work and learn as a professional.

Teachers have been quitting more than any other profession long before their jobs were tied to their students' test scores (a recent phenomenon). About half quit in the first five years, a figure that should be shocking and should have been looked into a long time ago.

When I worked for corporate America, I was given an "exit interview" when I left for another firm. When I left teaching, no one ever asked why, or cared. That's the problem -- or one of them.

Ask any teacher what they need to do a better job and it's smaller classes, on-the-job training and time to observe respected teachers in their subject. And respect would help, support from parents and administrators. The public, too.

Ever since the economic recession of 2008, the demonization of teachers, teachers' unions and public schools has been little short of a Salem witch trial while people who not only don't do their jobs, but steal us blind, go unmentioned. If what we want are a group of professionals who do a good job and want to stay in that job, we're certainly going about it the wrong way.

Procedures currently performed in doctors offices, without the stringent requirements in the abortion specific laws include:

1. Colonoscopies, with potential for hemorrhage, perforation of bowels, sepsis and death.
2. Liposuction, similar to suction abortion, but far more complex, with greater chance of complications and death.
3. Botox injections with serious reactions.
4. Allergy testing with potential for anaphylaxis and death.
5. Cardiac stress tests with potential to heart attacks and death.
...
I can go on. The list is long.

If patient safety is our main concern let us look at all medical procedures and look for ways (regardless of cost) to find solutions. Singling out abortion clinics, for higher standards in this regard, is dishonest at best.

Republican controlled State Assemblies have been enacting two abortion specific laws.

1. Require doctors performing abortions to have admitting privilege at a nearby hospital. The stated reason is that he/she should be available to treat complications.

2. Require abortions clinics to comply with expensive (unaffordable) building codes. The stated reason - patient safety.

We all know that both these claims are false. We all also know the real reason - make it harder for women to avail themselves of these (legal) medical services.

First, most doctors nowadays in many parts of the country do not have hospital privileges. They treat complex medical conditions in their offices, and refer patients to hospitalists when they need admission.

Second, doctors perform many procedures in their offices - endoscopies, cosmetic procedures, etc. (some far more dangerous than a simple first trimester abortion) without having to comply with building codes.

Let's be honest here. Don't hide behind feigned concern for the safety of our women. This is insulting to our intelligence.

Enough already! The offense here is that elected officials are once again trying to legislate away those laws that don't suit their political agenda. Don't like that abortion is legal? Let's create a law that will make it practically impossible to get one! Like it or not, abortion is legal in this country, and access to abortion services are guaranteed under the 14th Amendment of the constitution.

I'm pleased that Judge Yeakel rejected this attempt at side-stepping the law. It is offensive that Texas taxpayers must foot the bill for the time he spent to uphold the obvious. I suppose Texas has no other issues on its plate that need the attention of its officials.

I doubt the decision to have an abortion is ever easy. Still, women have the right to freely make such a choice, the same as all citizens of a certain age and status being able to cast their vote for the elected officials that will govern on their behalf. It is extremely disturbing that some conservative legislators (in Texas and elsewhere) feel their time is best spent trying to derail and frustrate these laws and rights that only they and their agenda seem to have an issue with. Enough already!

There is no silver bullet. This is a big problem for politicians. They desperately want to sell a simple answer: fire/punish teachers for low test scores (a sure-fire way to attract the best talent, especially to schools with the most disadvantaged students); reward a couple of teachers per school rather than lifting all boats; deregulate schools and provide vouchers; increase funding without either data or accountability; repeal teacher licensing requirements rather than improve teacher training; expand virtual schools; etc., etc., etc.

Taking on the hard slog of recognizing that there is no single panacea and creating a culture where policymakers collaborate with and respect the wisdom of actual service providers takes too much time away from fundraising events. Unfortunately, acknowledging that we still don't know how to leave no child behind on a large scale (despite pockets of success in individual schools) does not resonate in a political culture that values only the ends, while dismissing the means to achieve them.

I agree with you about abortion laws, but for every Republican-proposed abortion law ruled unconstitutional as a covert means to an end there is a Democrat-proposed gun law ruled unconstitutional for a similar reason.   Democrats are just about as deceptive when it comes to gun laws as  Republicans are with respect to abortion laws, and if you pretend otherwise, you're deceptive, too.

First: If you are suggesting that waiting a couple of weeks for a background check will change your body and put you at several times greater risk of illness or death, and that it will impose a two-decade-long moral and financial burden on you (as does an unwanted pregnancy), then you are wrong.

Second: Supporters of gun control are very open about our objectives - prevent gun violence. We support constitutionally mandated access to firearms so as to maintain "a well-regulated militia" which is "necessary to the security of a free state" because it is a part of our Constitution. But note that the 2nd amendment says that gun ownership should be "well-regulated." There is no deception in trying to regulate gun ownership under the 2nd amendment. On the other hand, supporters of the Texas abortion regulations would put the living human carrying the fetus in greater danger of harm, illness and death, than she is already, while claiming that the regulations are for her safety. That's deception.

The ruling requiring clinics to meet hospital standards is similar in intent to new ID voting requirements. They are both Conservative/Republican covert means to an end. Ends they have concluded is the only right end.

Hospital-like requirements, which naturally clincs can't achieve, essentially prevent women from having the right to choose. ID requirements--in addition to changing location and time people can register and vote-- restricts the constitutional rights of Democratic-leaning minorities and students by making it difficult for both grroups to get to the polls and vote.

Control through underhandedness and deception, is not only unattractive and shameful. it does not a democracy make. Freedom does. Freedom to choose and freedom to vote for party of choice does. Or haven't they heard.
